sp.l: Yes, you may live: but —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Finely butted doctor.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Do not discourage him.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: He must be told truth,
'Tis now too late to trifle. Enter Dem. and gent.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Here the prince comes.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How now gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Be wailing sir, a soldier,
And one I think, your grace will grieve to part with,
But every living thing —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis true, must perish,
Our lives are but our marches to our graves,
How dost thou now lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Faith 'tis true sir,
We are but spans, and candles ends.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He's finely mortified.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art heart whole yet; I see he alters strangely,
And that a pace too; I saw it this morning in him,
When he poor man, I dare swear —

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: No believe't sir,
I never felt it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here's lies the pain now: how he is swelled?

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: The impostume
Fed with a new malignant humour now,
Will grow to such a bigness, 'tis incredible,
The compass of a bushel will not hold it,
And with such a hell of torture it will rise too. —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Can you endure me touch it?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: O, I beseech you sir:
I feel you sensibly ere you come near me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: He's finely wrought, he must be cut, no cure else,
And suddenly, you see how fast he blows out.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Good master doctor, let me be beholding to you,
I feel I cannot last.

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: For what lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: But e'en for half a dozen cans of good wine,
That I may drink my will out: I faint hideously.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Fetch him some wine; and since he must go gentlemen
Why let him take his journey merrily. Enter servant with wine.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: That's e'en the nearest way.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I could laugh dead now.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here, off with that.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: These two I give your grace,
A poor remembrance of a dying man sir,
And I beseech you wear 'em out.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will soldier,
These are fine legacies.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Among the gentlemen,
Even all I have left; I am a poor man, naked,
Yet something for remembrance: four a piece gentlemen,
And so my body where you please.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It will work.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I make your grace my executor, and I beseech ye
See my poor will fulfilled: sure I shall walk else.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: As full as they can be filled, here's my hand soldier.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: The wine will tickle him.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I would hear a drum beat,
But to see how I could endure it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Beat a drum there. Drum within.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: O heavenly music, I would hear one sing to't,
I am very full of pain.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Sing? 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Why, then I would drink a drum full:
Where lies the enemy?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Why, here close by.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now he begins to muster.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: And dare ye fight?
Dare ye fight gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: You must not cut him:
He's gone then in a moment; all the hope left, is
To work his weakness into sudden anger,
And make him raise his passion above his pain,
And so dispose him on the enemy;
His body then, being stirred with violence,
Will purge itself and break the sore.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis true sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: And then my life for his.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I will not die thus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: But he is too weak to do —

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Die like a dog?

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: Ay, he's weak, but yet he's heart whole.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: An excellent sign.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stronger still, and better.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Hem, hem; tan, tan, tan, tan, tan. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: Now he's i'th' way on't.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Well go thy ways, thou wilt do something certain.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And some brave thing, or let mine ears be cut off.
He's finely wrought.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Let's after him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I pray sir;
But how this rogue, when this cloud's melted in him,
And all discovered. —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: That's for an after mirth, away, away, away. Ex.

div.head: Scene 6.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Let no man fear to die: we love to sleep all,
And death is but the sounder sleep; all ages,
And all hours call us; 'tis so common, easy,
That little children tread those paths before us;
We are not sick, nor our souls pressed with sorrows,
Nor go we out like tedious tales, forgotten;
High, high we come, and hearty to our funerals,
And as the sun that sets, in blood let's fall.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: 'Tis true, they have us fast, we cannot scape 'em,
Nor keeps the brow of fortune one smile for us,
Dishonourable ends we can scape though,
And (Worse than those, captivities) we can die,
And dying nobly, though we leave behind us
These clods of flesh, that are too massy burdens,
Our living souls fly crowned with living conquests.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: They have begun, fight bravely, and fall bravely;
And may that man that seeks to save his life now
By price, or promise, or by fear falls from us,Enter a soldier
Never again be blessed with name of soldier.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: How now? who charged first? I seek a brave hand
To set me off in death.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: We are not charged sir,
The prince lies still.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: How comes this latum up then?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: There is one desperate fellow, with the devil in him
(He never durst do this else) has broke into us,
And here he bangs ye two or three before him,
There five or six; ventures upon whole companies.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: And is not seconded?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Not a man follows.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Nor cut a pieces?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Their wonder yet has stayed 'em.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Let's in, and see this miracle?

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: I admire it. Ex.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Fetch him off, fetch him off; I am sure he's clouted;
Did I not tell you how 'twould take?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: 'Tis admirable.

div.stage: Enter lieutenant with colours in his hand, pursuing 3 or 4 soldiers.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Follow that blow, my friend, there's at your coxcombs,
I fight to save me from the surgeon's miseries.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How the knave curries 'em?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: You cannot rogues,
Till you have my diseases, fly my fury,
Ye bread and butter rogues, do ye run from me?
And my side would give me leave, I would so hunt ye,
Ye porridge gutted slaves, ye veal-broth boobies.

div.stage: Enter Demetrius, and physicians, and gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Enough, enough lieutenant, thou hast done bravely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Mirror of man.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: There's a flag for ye sir,
I took it out o'th' shop, and never paid for't,
I'll to 'em again, I am not come to th' text yet.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: No more my soldier: beshrew my heart he is hurt sore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hang him, he'll lick all those whole.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: Now will we take him,
And cure him in a trice.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Be careful of him.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Let me live but two years,
And do what ye will with me;
I never had but two hours yet of happiness;
Pray ye give me nothing to provoke my valour,
For I am e'en as weary of this fighting —

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: Ye shall have nothing; come to the prince's tent
And there the surgeons presently shall search ye,
Then to your rest.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: A little handsome litter
To lay me in, and I shall sleep.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Look to him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I do believe a horse begotten this fellow,
He never knew his strength yet; they are our own.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I think so, I am cozened else; I would but see now
A way to fetch these off, and save their honours.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Only their lives.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Pray ye take no way of peace now,
Unless it be with infinite advantage.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I shall be ruled;
Let the battles now move forward,Ent. trumpet and Herold.
Ourself will give the signal:
Now Herold, what's your message?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.l: From my masters
This honourable courtesy, a parley
For half an hour, no more sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Let 'em come on,
They have my princely word.

div.stage: Enter Seleucus, Lysimacus, Ptolemy, attendants, soldiers,

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.l: They are here to attend ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Now princes, your demands?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Peace, if it may be
Without the too much tainture of our honour:
Peace, and we'll buy it too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: At what price?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Tribute.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: At all the charge of this war.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That will not do.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Leontius, you and I have served together,
And run through many a fortune with our swords,
Brothers in wounds, and health; one meat has fed us,
One tent a thousand times from cold night covered us:
Our loves have been but one; and had we died then,
One monument had held our names, and actions:
Why do you set upon your friends such prizes?
And sacrifice to giddy chance such trophies?
Have we forgotten to die? or are our virtues
Less in afflictions constant, than our fortunes?
Ye are deceived old soldier.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know your worths,
And thus low bow in reverence to your virtues:
Were these my wars, or lead my power in chief here,
I knew then how to meet your memories:
They are my King's employments; this man fights now,
To whom I owe all duty, faith, and service;
This man that fled before ye; call back that,
That bloody day again, call that disgrace home,
And then an easy peace, may sheathe our swords up.
I am not greedy of your lives and fortunes,
Nor do I gape ungratefully to swallow ye,
Honour the spur of all illustrious natures,
That made you famous soldiers, and next Kings,
And not ambitious envy strikes me forward,
Will ye unarm, and yield yourselves his prisoners?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: We never knew what that sound meant: no gives
Shall ever bind this body, but embraces;
Nor weight of sorrow here, till earth fall on me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Expect our charge then.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: 'Tis the nobler courtesy:
And so we leave the hand of heaven to bless us.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stay, have you any hope?

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: We have none left us,
But that one comfort of our deaths together;
Give us but room to sight.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Win it, and wear it.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Call from the hills those companies hang o'er us
Like bursting clouds; and then break in, and take us.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Find such a soldier will forsake advantage,
And we'll draw off, to show I dare be noble,
And hang a light out to ye in this darkness,
The light of peace; give up those cities, forts,
And all those frontier countries to our uses.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Is this the peace? traitors to those that feed us,
Our gods and people? give our countries from us?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Begin the knell, it sounds a great deal sweeter.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Let lose your servant death.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Fall fate upon us,
Our memories shall never stink behind us.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Seleucus, great Seleucus,

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: The prince calls sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou stock of nobleness, and courtesy,
Thou father of the war —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What means the prince now?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Give me my standard here.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: His anger's melted.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You gentlemen that were his prisoners,
And felt the bounty of that noble nature,
Lay all your hands, and bear these colours to him,
The standard of the kingdom; take it soldier.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: What will this mean?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou hast won it, bear it off,
And draw thy men home whilst we wait upon thee.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You shall have all our countries.

sp.speaker: Lys. Ptol.
sp.l: All by heaven sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will not have a stone, a bush, a bramble,
No, in the way of courtesy, I'll start ye;
Draw off, and make a lane through all the army,
That these that have subdued us, may march through us.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir, do not make me surfeit with such goodness,
I'll bear your standard for ye; follow ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I swear it shall be so, march through me fairly,
And thine be this day's honour, great Seleucus.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Mirror of noble minds.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Nay then ye hate me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I cannot speak now:Ex with drums, and shouts.
Well, go thy ways, at a sure piece of bravery
Thou art the best, these men are won by th' necks now:
I'll send a post away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No aptness in her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Not an immodest motion,
And yet when she is as free, and when she is courted,
Makes as wild witty answers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This more fires me,
I must not have her thus.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: We cannot alter her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Have ye put the youths upon her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: All that know any thing,
And have been studied how to catch a beauty,
But like so many whelps about an elephant —
The prince is coming home sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I hear that too,
But that's no matter; am I altered well;

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Not to be known I think sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I must see her. Ent. 2 gent. or lords.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I offered all I had, all I could think of,
I tried her through all the points o'th' compass, I think.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: She studies to undo the court, to plant here
The enemy to our age, chastity;
She is the first, that ere balked a close arbour,
And the sweet contents within: she hates curled heads too,
And setting up or beards she swears, is idolatry.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I never knew so fair a face so froze;
Yet she would make one think —

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: True by her carriage,
For she's as wanton as a kid toth' out side,
As full of mocks and taunts: I kissed her hand too,
Walked with her half an hour.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: She heard me sing,
And sung herself too; she sings admirably;
But still, when any hope was, as 'tis her trick
To minister enough of those, then presently
With some new flame or other, nothing to th' matter,
And such a frown, as would sink all before her,
She takes her chamber; come we shall not be the last fools.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Not by a hundred I hope; 'tis a strange wench.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This screws me up still higher. Enter Celia, and ladies behind her

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Here she comes sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then be you gone: and take the women with ye,
And lay those jewels in her way.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If I stay longer
I shall number as many lovers as Lais did;
How they flock after me? upon my conscience,
I have had a dozen horses given me this morning,
I'll e'en set up a troop, and turn she-souldier.
A good discreet wench now, that were not hidebound
Might raise a fine estate here, and suddenly:
For these warm things will give their souls — I can go nowhere
Without a world of offerings to my excellence:
I am a Queen, a goddess, I know not what —
And no constellation in all heaven, but I outshine it;
And they have found out now I have no eyes
Of mortal lights, but certain influences,
Strange virtuous lightnings, humane nature starts at,
And I can kill my twenty in a morning,
With as much case now —
Ha? what are these? new projects?
Where are my honourable ladies? are you out too?
Nay then I must buy the stock, send me good carding:
I hope the prince's hand, be not in this sport;
I have not seen him yet, cannot hear from him,
And that, that, troubles me: all these were recreations
Had I but his sweet company to laugh with me:
What fellows that? another apparition?
This is the lovingest age: I should know that face,
Sure I have seen't before, not long since neither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She sees me now: oh heaven, a most rare creature!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis the same: I will take no notice of ye,
But if I do not fit ye, let me fry for't;
Is all this cackling for your egg? they are fair ones,
Excellent rich no doubt to; and may stumble
A good staid mind, but I can go thus by 'em;
My honest friend; do you set off these jewels?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Set 'em off, lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I mean, sell 'em here sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She's very quick; for sale they are not meant sure.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For sanctity I think much less: good even sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, noble lady stay: 'tis you must wear 'em:
Never look strange, they are worthy your best beauty.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Did ye speak to me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To you or to none living:
To you they are sent; to you they are sacrificed.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'll never look a horse i'th' mouth that's given:
I thank ye sir: I'll send one to reward ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do you never ask who scent 'em?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Never I:
Nor never care, if it be an honest end,
That end's the full reward, and thanks but slubbers it;
If it be ill, I will not urge the acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This has a soul indeed: pray let me tell ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I care not if ye do, so you do it handsomely,
And not stand picking of your words,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The King sent 'em.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Away, away, thou art some foolish fellow,
And now I think thou hast stole 'em too; the King sent 'em?
Alas good man, wouldst thou make me believe
He has nothing to do with things of these worths,
But wantonly to fling'em ? he's an old man,
A good old man, they say too: I dare swear
Full many a year ago, he left these gambols:
Here, take your trinkets.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sure I do not lie lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know thou liest extremely, damnably.
Thou hast a lying face.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I was never thus rattled.

sp.speaker: Cel,
sp.l: But say I should believe: why are these sent me?
And why art thou the messenger? who art thou?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lady, look on 'em wisely, and then consider
Who can send such as these, but a King only?
And, to what beauty can they be oblations,
But only yours? For me that am the carrier,
'Tis only fit you know I am his servant,
And have fulfilled his will.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You are short and pithy;
What must my beauty do for these?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sweet lady,
You cannot be so hard of understanding,
When a King's favour shines upon ye gloriously,
And speaks his love in these, —

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O then love's the matter;
Sir-reverence love: now I begin to feel ye:
And I should be the King's whore, a brave title.
And go as glorious as the sun, o brave still:
The chief commandress of his concubines,
Hurried from place to place to meet his pleasures.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A devilish subtle wench, but a rare spirit.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And when the good old sponge had sucked my youth dry,
And left some of his royal aches in my bones:
When time shalt tell me I have ploughed my life up,
And cast long furrows in my face to sink me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You must not think so lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Then can these sir,
These precious things, the price of youth and beauty;
This shop here of sin-offerings set me off again?
Can it restore me chaste, young innocent?
Purge me to what I was? add to my memory
An honest and a noble fame? The King's device;
The sin's as universal as the sun is,
And lights an everlasting torch to shame me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do you hold so sleight account of a great King's favour,
That all knees bow to purchase?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Prithee peace:
If thou knewest how ill-fauouredly thy tale becomes thee,
And what ill root it takes —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You will be wiser.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Could the King find no shape to shift his pander into,
But reverend age? and one so like himself too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She has found me out.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Cousin the world with gravity?
Prithee resolve me one thing, does the King love thee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I think he does.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It seems so by thy office:
He loves thy use, and when that's ended, hates thee:
Thou seemest to me a soldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes I am one.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And hast fought for thy country?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Many a time.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: May be, commanded too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have done, lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O wretched man, below the state of pity!
Canst thou forget, thou wert begotten in honour?
A free companion for a King? A soldier?
Whose nobleness dare feel no want, but enemies?
Canst thou forget this, and decline so wretchedly,
To eat the bread of bawdry, of base bawdry?
Feed on the scum of sin? fling thy sword from thee?
Dishonour to the noble name that nursed thee?
Go, beg diseases: let them be thy armours,
Thy fights, the flames of lust, and their foul issues.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why then I am a King, and mine own speaker.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And I as free as you, mine own disposer;
There take your jewels; let them give them lustres
That have dark lives and souls; wear 'em yourself sir,
You'll seem a devil else.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I command ye stay.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Be just, I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will not wrong ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Then thus low falls my duty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can ye love me?
Say I, and all I have.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I cannot love ye;
Without the breach of faith I cannot hear ye;
Ye hang upon my love, like frosts on lilies:
I can die, but I cannot love: you are answered. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I must find apter means, I love her truly. Exit.

div.head: Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Ent. demetr. Leon. Lieut. gent. soldier. And host.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Hither do you say she is come?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes sir, I am sure on't:
For whilst I waited on ye, putting my wife in trust,
I know not by what means, but the King found her,
And hither she was brought; how, or to what end.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My father found her?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: So my wife informs me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Leontius, pray draw off the soldiers,
I would a while be private.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Fall off gentlemen,
The prince would be alone. Ex. leo. And Sol.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is he so cunning?
There is some trick in this, and you must know it,
And be an agent too: which if it prove so —

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Pull me to pieces sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My father found her?
My father brought her hither? went she willingly?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: My wife says full of doubts.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I cannot blame her
No more: there's no trust, no faith in mankind.

div.stage: Enter Antigonus, Menippus, Leontius, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Keep her up close, he must not come to see her:
You are welcome nobly now, welcome home gentlemen;
You have done a courteous service on the enemy;
Has tied his faith for ever; you shall find it;
Ye are not now in's debt son: still your sad looks:
Leontius, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Truth sir, I know not,
We have been merry since we went.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I feel it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, what's the matter now? do you want money?
Sure he has heard o'th' wench.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is that a want sir?
I would fain speak to your grace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You may do freely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And not deserve your anger?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That ye may too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: There was a gentle woman, and sometimes my prisoner,
Which I thought well of sir: your grace conceives me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do indeed, and with much grief conceive ye;
With full as much grief as your mother bore me:
There was such a woman: would I might as well say,
There was no such Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: She was virtuous,
And therefore not unfit my youth to love her:
She was as fair —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Her beauty I'll proclaim too,
To be as rich as ever reigned in woman;
But how she made that good, the devil knows.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: She was — oh heaven!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The hell to all thy glories,
Swallowed thy youth, made shipwreck of thine honour:
She was a devil.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye are my father sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And since ye take a pride to show your follies,
I'll muster 'em, and all the world shall view 'em.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What heat is this? the King's eyes speak his anger?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou hast abused thy youth; drawn to thy fellowship
In stead of arts and arms, a woman's kisses,
The subtleties, and soft heats of a harlot.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Good sir, mistake her not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A witch, a sorcerer:
I tell thee but the truth; and hear Demetrius,
Which has so dealt upon thy blood with charms,
Devilish and dark; so locked up all thy virtues;
So plucked thee back from what thou sprungst from, glorious
In heaven, that any tongue but his durst say this;
That any heart durst harbour it: dread father,
If for the innocent the gods allow us
To bend our knees —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away, thou art bewitched still;
Though she be dead, her power still lives upon thee.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Dead? O sacred sir: dead did you say?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She is dead fool.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: It is not possible: be not so angry,
Say she is fallen under your sad displeasure,
Or any thing but dead, say she is banished,
Invent a crime, and do believe it sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dead by the law: we found her hell, and her,
I mean her charms and spells, for which she perished;
And she confessed she drew thee to thy ruin,
And purposed it, purposed my empire's overthrow.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: But is she dead? was there no pity sir?
If her youth erred, was there no mercy shown her?
Did ye look on her face, when ye condemned her?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I looked into her heart, and there she was hideous.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Can she be dead? can virtue fall untimely?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She is dead, deservingly she died.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I have done then.
O matchless sweetness, whither art thou vanished?
O thou fair soul of all thy sex, what paradise
Hast thou enriched and blessed? I am your son sir,
And to all you shall command stand most obedient,
Only a little time I must entreat you
To study to forget her; 'twill not belong sir,
Nor I long after it: art thou dead Celia,
Dead my poor wench? my joy, plucked green with violence:
Oh fair sweet flower, farewell: come, thou destroyer,
Sorrow, thou melter of the soul, dwell with me;
Dwell with me solitary thoughts, tears, cryings,
Nothing that loves the day, love me, or seek me,
Nothing that loves his own life haunt about me:
And love, I charge thee, never charm mine eyes more,
Nor never betray a beauty to my curses:
For I shall curse all now hate all, forswear all,
And all the brood of fruitful nature vex at,
For she is gone that was all, and I nothing —Ex. and Gen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This opinion must be maintained.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It shall be sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let him go: I can at mine own pleasure
Draw him to'th' right again: wait you instructions,
And see the soldier paid, Leontius:
Once more ye are welcome home all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Health to your majesty. —Exit Antig. etc.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou wentest along the journey, how canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I did, but I am sure 'tis so: had I stayed behind,
I think this had not proved.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A wench the reason?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Who's that talks of a wench there?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All this discontent
About a wench.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Where is this wench, good colonel?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Prithee hold thy peace: who calls thee to counsel?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Why, if there be a wench —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis fit thou know her:Enter 2 Gen.
That I'll say for thee, and as fit thou art for her,
Let her be mewed or stopped: how is it gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 1. G.
sp.l: He's wondrous discontent, he'll speak to no man.

sp.speaker: 2. G.
sp.l: Has taken his chamber close, admits no entrance;
Tears in his eyes, and cryings out.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'Tis so sir,
And now I wish myself half hanged ere I went this journey,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What is this woman?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I cannot tell ye,
But handsome as heaven.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: She is not so high I hope sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Ay, that would be known.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why sirrah.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I cannot show ye neither;
The King has now disposed of her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There lies the matter:
Will he admit none to come to comfort him?

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Not any near, nor let 'em knock their hearts out,
Will never speak.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: 'Tis the best way if he have her;
For look you, a man would be loath to be disturbed in's pastime;
'Tis every good man's case.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis all thy living,
We must not suffer this, we dare not suffer it:
For when these tender souls meet deep afflictions,
They are not strong enough to struggle with 'em,
But drop away as snow does, from a mountain,
And in the torrent of their own sighs sink themselves:
I will, and must speak to him.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: So must I too:
He promised me a charge.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Of what? of children
Upon my conscience, thou hast a double company,
And all of thine own begetting already.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: That's all one,
I'll raise 'em to a regiment, and there command 'em,
When they turn disobedient, unbeget 'em:
Knock 'em o'th' head, and put in new.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A rare way;
But for all this, thou art not valiant enough
To dare to see the prince now?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Do ye think he's angry?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Extremely vexed.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: To the endangering of any man comes near him.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Yet, if thou couldst but win him out,
Whatever thy suit were.
Believe it granted presently.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yet thou must think though,
That in the doing he may break upon ye,
And —

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: If he do not kill me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There's the question.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: For half a dozen hurts?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Art thou so valiant?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Not absolutely so neither: no it cannot be,
I want my impostumes, and my things about me,
Yet I'll make danger, colonel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Twill be rare sport,
Howe'er it take; give me thy hand; if thou dost this,
I'll raise thee up a horse troop, take my word for't.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: What may be done by humane man?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let's go then.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.p: Away before the cool: he will revenge else. Ex.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Will she not yield?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: For all we can urge to her;
I swore I would marry her, she laughed extremely,
And then she railed like thunder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Call in the magician. Enter Mag. with a bowl.
I must, and will obtain her, I am ashes else.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.l: Are all the philters in? charms, powders, roots?
They are all in: and now I only stay
The invocation of some helping spirits.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To your work then, and dispatch.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.l: Sit still, and fear not.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I shall never endure these fights.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away with the woman: go wait without.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: When the devils gone prey call me. Exit.
Be sure you make it powerful enough.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.l: Pray doubt not. — he conjures.
Rise from the shades below,
All you that prove
The helps of loose love;
Rise and bestow
Upon this cup, whatever may compel
By powerful charm, and unresisted spell.
A heart unwarmed to melt in love's desires,
Distil into this liquor all your fires;
Heats, longings, tears,
But keep back frozen fears,
That she may know, that has all power defied,
Art is a power that will not be denied.
I obey, I obey,
And am come to view e'er day
Brought along, all may compel,
All the earth has, and one hell:
Here's a little little flower.
This will make her sweat an hour,
Then unto such flames arise,
A thousand joys will not suffice.
Here's the powder of the moon
With which she caught Endymion,
The powerful tears that Venus cried,
When the boy Adonis died.
Here's Medea's charm, with which
Jason's heart she did bewitch,
Omphale this spell put in
When she made the Libyan spin.
This dull root plucked from Lethe stood,
Purges all pure thoughts, and good.
These I stir thus, round, round, round,
Whilst our light feet beat the ground.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.l: Now sir 'tis full, and whosoever drinks this
Shall violently dote upon your person,
And never sleep nor eat unsatisfied:
So many hours 'twill work, and work with violence,
And those expired 'tis done. You have my art sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: See him rewarded liberally — Leucippe.
Here, take this bowl, and when she calls for wine next —

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Be sure you give her this, and see her drink it;
Delay no time when she calls next.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let none else touch it on your life.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I am charged sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now if she have an antidote art let her scape me.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: There's the door lieutenant, if you dare do any thing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Here's no man waits.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Has given a charge that none shall,
Nor none shall come within the hearing of him:
Dare ye go forward?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Let me put on my skull first.
My head's almost beaten into th'pap of an apple.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Are there no guns i'th' door?
The rogue will do it,
And yet I know he has no stomach to't.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: What loopholes are there when I knock for stones,
For those may pepper me? I can perceive none.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How he views the fortification.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Farewell gentlemen,
If I be killed —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We'll see thee buried bravely.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Away: how should I know that then? I'll knock softly.
Pray heaven he speak in a low voice now to comfort me:
I feel I have no heart to't: — is't well, gentlemen.
Colonel, my troop —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A little louder.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Stay, stay;
Here is a window, I will see, stand wide.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By — he's charging of a gun:
There's no such matter.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: There's nobody in this room.
O 'twas a fire-shovel:
Now I'll knock louder: if he say who's there,
As sure he has so much manners, then will I answer himKnock louder,
So finely and demurely: my troop colonel —

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Knock louder fool, he hears not.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: You fool, do you.
Do and ye dare now.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I do not undertake it.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Then hold your peace, and meddle with your own matters.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now he will knock. Knocks louder.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Sir, sir: wil't please you hear sir?
Your grace: I'll look again: what's that?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He's there now.
Lord! How he stares! I never yet saw him thus altered:
Stand now, and take the troop.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Would I were in't,
And a good horse under me: I must knock again.
The devil's at my finger's ends: he comes now.
Now colonel, if I live —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The troop's thine own boy. Enter Dem. a pistol.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What desperate fool, ambitious of his ruin?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Your father would desire ye, sit, to come to dinner.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art no more,

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Now, now, now, now.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Poor coxcomb,
Why do I aim at thee? Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: His fear has killed him. En. Leuc. with a bowl.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: I protest he's almost stiff: bend him, and rub him:
Hold his nose close, you, if you be a woman,
Help us a little: here's a man near perished.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Alas, alas, I have nothing here about me.
Look to my bowl: I'll run in presently
And fetch some waters: bend him, and set him upwards.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A goodly man. —Exit.
Here's a brave heart: he's warm again: you shall not

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Leave us i'th' lurch so, sirrah.
Now he breathes too.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: If we had but any drink to raise his spirits.
What's that i'th' bowl? upon my life good liquor,
She would not own it else.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: He sees.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Look up boy,
And take this cup, and drink it off, I'll pledge thee,
Guide it to his mouth: he swallows heartily.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: Oh! fear and sorrows dry; 'tis off —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Stand up man.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Am I not shot?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Away with him, and cheer him:
Thou hast won thy troop.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I think I won it bravely.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Go, I must see the prince, he must not live thus;
And let me hear an hour hence from ye.
Well sir —Ex. Gen. and Lieu.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Here, here: where's the sick gentleman?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He's up and gone, lady.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Alas: that I came so late.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He must still thank ye,
Ye left that in a cup here did him comfort.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: That in the bowl?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes truly, very much comfort,
He drank it off, and after it spoke lustily.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Did he drink it all?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All off.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: The devil choke him,
I am undone: 'Has twenty devils in him,
Undone for ever: left he none?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I think not.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: No not a drop: what shall become of me now?
Had he nowhere else to swoon? A vengeance swoon him:
Undone, undone, undone: stay, I can lie yet,
And swear too at a pinch, that's all my comfort,Ent. De.
Look to him; I say look to him, and but mark what follows.Ex

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What a devil ails the woman? here comes the prince again,
With such a sadness on his face, as sorrow,
Sorrow herself, but poorly imitates.
Sorrow of sorrows on that heart that caused it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Why might she not be false and treacherous to me?
And found so by my father? she was a woman,
And many a one of that sex, young and fair,
As full of faith as she have fallen, and foully.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It is a wench: oh that I knew the circumstance.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Why might not, to preserve me from this ruin,
She having lost her honour, and abused me,
My father chance the forms o'th' coins, and execute
His anger on a fault she never committed,
Only to keep me safe? why should I think so?
She never was to me but all obedience,
Sweetness, and love.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How heartily he weeps now?
I have not wept these thirty years and upward;
But now, if I should be hanged I cannot hold from't;
It grieves me to the heart.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Who's that that mocks me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A plague of him that mocks ye: I grieve truly,
Truly and heartily to see you thus sir:
And if it lay in my power, gods are my witness,
Who ere he be, that took your sweet peace from ye;
I am not so old yet, nor want I spirit —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: No more of that no more Leontius,
Revenges are the gods: our part is sufferance:
Farewell, I shall not see thee long.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Good sir, tell me the cause, I know there is a woman in't;
Do you hold me faithful? dare ye trust your soldier?
Sweet prince, the cause?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I must not, dare not tell it,
And as thou art an honest man, inquire not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will ye be merry then?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I am wondrous merry.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis wondrous well: you think now this becomes ye.
Shame on't, it does not sir, it shows not handsomely;
If I were thus, you would swear I were an ass straight;
A wooden ass; whine for a wench?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prithee leave me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will not leave ye for a fit.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Leontius?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: For that you may have anywhere for sixpence,
And a dear pennyworth too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Nay, than you are troublesome.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Not half so troublesome as you are to yourself sir;
Was that brave heart made to pant for a placket:
And now i'th' dog-days too, when nothing dare love?
That noble mind to melt away, and moulder
For a hay-nonny-nonny? would I had a glass here,
To show ye what a pretty toy ye are turned to.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My wretched fortune.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will ye but let me know her?
I'll once turn bawd: go too, they are good men's offices,
And not so contemptible as we take 'em for:
And if she be above ground, and a woman,
I ask no more; I'll bring her of my back sir,
By this hand I will: and I had as lief bring the devil,
I care not who she be, nor where I have her,
And in your arms, or the next bed deliver her,
Which you think fittest: and when you have danced your galliard.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Away, and fool to them are so affected:
Oh thou art gone, and all my comfort with thee;
Wilt thou do one thing for me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All things i'th' world sir,
Of all dangers.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Swear.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come near me no more than.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come no more near me:
Thou art a plague-sore to me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Give you good even sir;
If you be suffered thus, we shall have fine sport.
I will be sorry yet. Ent. 2 gent.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: How now, how does he?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nay, if I tell ye hang me, or any man else
That hath his nineteen wits; he has the bots I think,
He groans, and roars, and kicks.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Will be yet?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Not willingly:
Shortly he will not see a man; if ever
I looked upon a prince so metamorphized,
So juggled into I know not what, shame take me;
This 'tis to be in love.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Is that the cause on't?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What is it not the cause of but bear baitings?
And yet it stinks much like it: out upon't,
What giants, and what dwarfs, what owls and apes,
What dogs, and cats it makes us? men that are possessed with it,
Live as if they had a legion of devils in 'em,
And every devil of a several nature,
Nothing but heigh pass, repass: where's the lieutenant?
Has he gathered up the end on's wits again?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: He is alive: but you that talk of wonders,
Show me but such a wonder as he is now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why? he was ever at the worst a wonder.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: He is now most wonderful; a blazer now sir:

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What ails the fools? and what star reigns now gentlemen
We have such prodigies?

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: 'Twill pose your heaven-hunters;
He talks now of the King, no other language,
And with the King, as he imagines hourly,
Courts the King, drinks to the King, dies for the King,
Buys all the pictures of the King, wears the King's colours,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Does he not lie i'th' King's street too?

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: He's going thither,
Makes prayers for the King in sundry languages,
Turns all his proclamations into meeter,
Is really in love with the King, most dotingly,
And swears Adonis was a devil to him:
A sweet King, a most comely King, and such a King —

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: Then down on's marrowbones: oh excellent King:
Thus he begins, thou light and life of creatures,
Angel-eyed King, vouchsafe at length thy favour;
And so proceeds to incision: what think ye of this sorrow?

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Will as familiarly kiss the King's horses
As they pass by him: ready to ravish his footmen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why this is above Ela?
But how comes this?

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Nay that's to understand yet,
But thus it is, and this part but the poorest,
'Twould make a man leap over the moon to see him act these.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: With sighs as though his heart would break:
Cry like a breeched boy, not eat a bit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I must go see him presently,
For this is such a gig: for certain gentlemen
The fiend rides on a fiddlestick.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Can ye guide me to him? for half an hour I am his,
To see the miracle.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: We sure shall start him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you sure she drank it?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Now must I lie most confidently.
Yes sir, she has drunk it off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How works it with her?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I see no alteration yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There will be,
For he is the greatest artist living made it;
Where is she now?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: She is ready to walk out sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Starke mad, I know she will be.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: So I hope sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She knows not of the prince?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Of no man living —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How do I look! how do my clothes become me?
I am not very grey.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A very youth sir,
Upon my maidenhead as smug as April:
Heaven bless that sweet face, 'twill undo a thousand,
Many a soft heart must sob yet, ere that wither,
Your grace can give content enough. Enter Celia with a book

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Here she comes sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How shall I keep her off me?
Go and perfume the room: make all things ready. Ex. Leu.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No hope yet of the prince? no comfort of him?
They keep me mewed up here, as they mew mad folks,
No company but my afflictions.
This royal devil again? strange, how he haunts me?
How like a poisoned potion his eyes fright me?
Has made himself handsome too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do you look now, lady?
You will leap anon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Curled and perfumed? I smell him:
He looks on's legs too: sure he will cut a caper,
Godamercy dear December.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O do you smile now:
I knew it would work with you: come hither pretty one.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I like those courtesies well come hither and kiss me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am reading sir of a short treatise here,
That's called the vanity of lust: has your grace seen it?
He says here, that an old man's loose desire
Is like the glowworms light, the apes so wondered at:
Which when they gathered sticks, and laid upon't,
And blew, and blew, turned tail, and went out presently:
And in another place, he calls their loves,
Faint smells of dying flowers, carry no comforts;
They're doting stinking fogs, so thick and muddy,
Reason with all his beams cannot beat through 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How's this? is this the potion? you but fool still,
I know you love me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: As ye are just and honest,
I know I love and honour ye: admire ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This makes against me, fearfully against me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But as you bring your power to persecute me,
Your traps to catch mine innocence, to rob me,
As you lay out your lusts to overwhelm me,
Hell never hated good, as I hate you sir;
And I dare tell it to your face: what glory
Now after all your conquests got, your titles,
The everliving memories raised to you.
Can my defeat be? my poor wrack, what triumph?
And when you crown your swelling cups to fortune,
What honourable tongue can sing my story?
Be as your emblem is, a glorious lamp
Set on the top of all, to light all perfectly:
Be as your office is, a god like justice,
Into all shedding equally your virtues.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She has drenched me now: now I admire her goodness;
So young, so nobly strong, I never tasted:
Can nothing in the power of Kings persuade ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, nor that power command me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Say I should force ye?
I have it in my will.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: Your will's a poor one;
And though it be a King's will, a despised one,
Weaker than infant's legs, your will's in swaddling clouts:
A thousand ways my will has found to check ye;
A thousand doors to leap ye I dare die sir
As suddenly I dare die, as you can offer:
Nay, say you had your will, say you had ravished me,
Performed your lust, what had you purchased by it?
What honour won, do you know who dwells above sir,
And what they have prepared for men turned devils?
Did you never hear their thunder? start and tremble,
Death sitting on your blood, when their fires visit us?
Will nothing wring you then do you think? sit hard here?
And like a snail curl round about your conscience
Biting and stinging: will you not roar too late then?
Then when you shake in horror of this villainy,
Then will I rise a star in heaven, and scorn ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lust, how I hate thee now? and love this sweetness?
Will ye be my Queen? can that price purchase ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not all the world, I am a Queen already;
Crowned by his love, I must not lose for fortune;
I can give none away, sell none away sir,
Can lend no love, am not mine own exchequer;
For in another's heart my hope and peace lies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your fair hands, lady: for yet I am not pure enough
To touch these lips, in that sweet peace ye spoke of:
Live now for ever, and I to serve your virtues —

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Why now ye show a god? now I kneel to ye;
This sacrifice of virgin's joy send to ye:
Thus I hold up my hands to heaven that touched ye,
And pray eternal blessings dwell about ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Virtue commands the stars: rise more than virtue;
Your present comfort shall be now my business.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: All my obedient service wait upon ye. Ex. severally.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hast thou clean forgotten the wars?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Prithee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: His mind's much elevated now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It serves so
Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I am so troubled with this fellow.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He will call me rogue anon.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: 'Tis ten to one else.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: O King, that thou knew'st I loved thee, how I loved thee:
And where oh King I barrel up thy beauty.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He cannot leave his sutler's trade, he woos in't.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: O never King.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By this hand, when I consider —

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: My honest friend, you are a little saucy.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: I told you you would have it.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: When mine own worth —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is flung into the balance, and found nothing.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: And yet a soldier.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And yet a saucy one.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: One that has followed thee.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Fair and far off.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Fought for thy grace.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Twas for some grief, you lie sir.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: He's the son of a whore denies this: will that satisfy ye?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Shall then that thing that honours thee?
How miserable a thing soever, yet a thing still;
And though a thing of nothing, thy thing ever.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Here's a new thing.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: He's in a deep dump now.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: I'll fetch him out on't. When's the King's birthday

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: When ere it be, that day I'll die with ringing,
And there's the resolution of a lover. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A goodly resolution sure I take it,
He is bewitched, or mooped, or his brains melted,
Could he find nobody to fall in love with; but the King,
The good old King, to dote upon him too?
Stay, now I remember what the fat woman warned me,
Bade me remember and look to him too:
I'll hang if she have not a hand in this: he's conjured,
Go after him. I pity the poor rascal,
In the mean time I'll wait occasion
To work upon the prince.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: Pray do that seriously. Ex. severally.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: He's very ill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am very sorry for't,
And much ashamed I have wronged his innocence,
Menippus, guide her to the prince's lodgings,
There leave her to his love again.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I am glad sir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: He will speak to none.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O I shall break that silence;
Be quick, take fair attendance.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yes sir presently. Ex.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He will find his tongue, I warrant ye; his health too;
I send a physic will not fail.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Fair work it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We hear the princes mean to visit us
In way of truce.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: 'Tis thought so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come: let's in then,
And think upon the noblest ways to meet 'em. Ex.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There's no way now to get in: all the lights stopped too;
Nor can I hear a sound of him: pray heaven
He use no violence: I think he has more soul
Stronger, and I hope nobler: would I could but see once
This beauty he groans under, or come to know
But any circumstance. What noise is that there?
I think I heard him groan: here are some coming;
A woman too, I'll stand aloof, and view 'em.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Well, some of ye have been too blame in this point,
But I forgive ye: the King might have picked out too
Some fitter woman to have tried his valour.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Twas all to the best meant, lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I must think so,
For how to mend it now: he's here you tell me?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: He's madam, and the joy to see you only
Will draw him out.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know that woman's tongue,
I think I have seen her face too: I'll go nearer:
If this be she, he has some cause of sorrow:
'Tis the same face; the same, most excellent woman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This should be lord Leontius: I remember him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Lady, I think ye know me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Speak soft, good soldier:
I do, and know ye worthy, know ye noble;
Know not me yet openly, as you love me;
But let me see ye again, I'll satisfy ye:
I am wondrous glad to see those eyes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You have charged me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You shall know where I am.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will not off yet:
She goes to knock at's door: this must be she
The fellow told me of: right glad I am on't,
He will bolt now for certain.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Are ye within sir?
I'll trouble you no more: I thank your courtesy,
Pray leave me now.

sp.speaker: All. Me.
sp.p: We rest your humble servants. Ex. men. Etc.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: So now my gyves are off: pray heaven he be here!
Master, my royal sir: do you hear who calls ye?
Love my Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: These are pretty quail-pipes,
The cork will come anon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Can ye be drowsy,
When I call at your window?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I hear him stirring:Enter Demetrius.
Now he comes wondering out.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis Gelia's sound sure:
The sweetness of that tongue draws all hearts to it;
There stands the shape too.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: How he stares upon her?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ha? do mine eyes abuse me?
'Tis she, the living Celia: your hand lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What should this mean?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The very self same Celia.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How do ye sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Only turned brave.
I heard you were dead my dear on: complete,
She is wondrous brave, a wondrous gallant courtier.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How he surveys me round? here has been foul play.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How came she thus?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It was a kind of death sir,
I suffered in your absence, moved up here,
And kept concealed I know not how.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis likely:
How came you hither Celia? wondrous gallant:
Did my father send for ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: So they told me sir,
And one command too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I hope you were obedient?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I was so ever.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And ye were bravely used?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I wanted nothing:
My maidenhead to a more i'th' sun, he's jealous:
I must now play the knave with him, to die for't,
'Tis in me nature.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Her very eyes are altered:
Jewels, and rich ones too, I never saw yet —
And what were those came for ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Monstrous jealous:
Have I lived at the rate of these scorned questions?
They seemed of good sort gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Kind men?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: They were wondrous kind:
I was much beholding to 'em;
There was one Menippus sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: One Menippus,
A notable merry lord, and a good companion.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And one Charinthus too?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes, there was such a one.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And Timon?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis most true.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And thou most treacherous:
My father's bawds by — they never miss course;
And were these daily with ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Every hour sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And was there not a lady, a fat lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O yes; a notable good wench:

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The devil fetch her.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis e'en the merriest wench —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Did she keep with ye too?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: She was all in all; my bedfellow, eat with me,
Brought me acquainted.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You are well known here then?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is no living here a stranger I think.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How came ye by this brave gown?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This is a poor one:
Alas, I have twenty richer: do you see these jewels?
Why, they are the poorest things, to those are sent me,
And sent me hourly too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is there no modesty?
No faith in this fair sex?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What will this prove too?
For yet with all my wits, I understand not.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come hither; thou art dead indeed, lost, tainted;
All that I left thee fair, and innocent,
Sweet as thy youth, and carrying comfort in't;
All that I hoped for virtuous, is fled from thee,
Turned 'Back, and bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By'r lady, this cuts shrewdly.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art dead, for ever dead; sins surfeit slew thee;
The ambition of those wanton eyes betrayed thee;
Go from me grave of honour; go thou foul one,
Thou glory of thy sin; go thou despised one,
And where there is no virtue, nor no virgin;
Where chastity was never known, nor heard of;
Where nothing reigns but imperious lust, and losers faces
Go thither, child of blood, and sing my doting.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You do not speak this seriously I hope sir;
I did but jest with you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Look not upon me,
There is more hell in those eyes, than hell harbours;
And when they flame, more torments.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dare ye trust me?
You durst once even with all you had: you love sir?
By this fair light I am honest.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou subtle Circe's,
Cast not upon the maiden light eclipses:
Curse not the day.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Come, come, you shall not do this:
How fain you would seem angry now, to fright me;
You are not in the field among your enemies;
Come, I must cool this courage.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Out thou impudence,
Thou ulcer of thy sex; when I first saw thee,
I drew into mine eyes mine own destruction,
I pulled into my heart that sudden poison,
That now consumes my dear content to cinders:
I am not now Demetrius, thou hast changed me;
Thou woman with thy thousand wiles hast changed me;
Thou serpent with thy angel-eyes haste slain me;
And where, before I touched on this fair ruin,
I was a man, and reason made, and moved me,
Now one great lump of grief. I grow and wander.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And as you are noble, do you think I did this?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Put all the devil's wings on, and fly from me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I will go from ye, never more to see ye:
I will fly from ye, as a plague hangs o'er me;
And through the progress of my life hereafter;
Wherever I shall find a fool, a false man,
One that never knew the worth of polished virtue;
A base suspecter of a virgin's honour,
A child that flings away the wealth he cried for,
Him will I call Demetrius: that fool Demetrius,
That mad man a Demetrius; and that false man,
The prince of broken faiths, even prince Demetrius.
You think now, I should cry, and kneel down to ye,
Petition for my peace; let those that feel here
The weight of evil, wait for such a favour,
I am above your hate, as far above it,
In all the actions of an innocent life,
As the pure stars are from the muddy meteors:
Cry when you know you folly: howl and curse then,
Beat that unmanly breast, that holds a false heart
When ye shall come to know, whom ye have flung from ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Pray ye stay a little.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not your hopes can alter me,
Then let a thousand back thoughts muster in ye,
And with those enter in a thousand dotings;
Those eyes be never shut, but drop to nothing:
My innocence for ever haunt and fright ye:
Those arms together grow in folds; that tongue,
That bold bad tongue that barks out these disgraces.
When you shall come to know how nobly virtuous
I have preserved my life, rot, rot within ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Live a lost man for ever.
Go ask your father's conscience what I suffered,
And through what seas of hazards I sailed through:
Mine honour still advanced in spite of tempests,
Then take your leave of love; and confess freely,
You were never worthy of this heart that served ye,
And so farewell ungrateful —Exit.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is she gone?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'll follow her, and will find out this matter. -Exit.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: Are ye pleased now? have you got your heart again?
Have I restored ye that?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Sir: even for heaven's sake,
And sacred truth' sake, tell me how ye found her.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: I will, and in few words. Before I tried her,
'Tis true, I thought her most unfit your fellowship,
And feared her too: which fear begotten that story
I told ye first: but since, like gold I touched her.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And how dear sir?

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: Heaven's holy light's not purer:
The constancy and goodness of all women
That ever lived, to win the names of worthy,
This noble maid has doubled in her: honour,
All promises of wealth, all art to win her,
And by all tongues employed, wrought as much on her
As one may do upon the sun at noon day
By lighting candles up: her shape is heavenly,
And to that heavenly shape her thoughts are angels.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Why did you tell me sir?

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I erred in't:
But since I made a full proof of her virtue,
I find a King too poor a servant for her.
Love her, and honour her; in all observe her.
She must be something more than time yet tells her:
And certain I believe him blessed, enjoys her:
I would not lose the hope of such a daughter,
To add another empire to my honour. —Exit.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O wretched state! to what end shall I turn me?
And where begins my penance? now, what service
Will win her love again? my death must do it:
And if that sacrifice can purge my follies,
Be pleased, oh mighty love, I die thy servant —Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know he does not deserve ye; has used ye poorly:
And to redeem himself —

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Redeem?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know it —
There's no way left:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For heaven's sake do not name him.
Do not think on him sir, he's so far from me
In all my thoughts now, methinks I never knew him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But yet I would see him again.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, never, never.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I do not mean to lend him any comfort;
But to afflict: him, so to torture him;
That even his very soul may shake within him:
To make him know, though he be great and powerful,
'Tis not within his aim to deal dishonourably,
And carry it off, and with a maid of your sort.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I most confess, I could most spitefully afflict him;
Now, now, I could whet my anger at him;
Now, armed with bitterness, I could shoot through him;
I long to vex him:

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And do it home, and bravely:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Were I a man?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I'll help that weakness in ye:
I honour ye, and serve ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not only to disclaim me,
When he had sealed his vows in heaven, sworn to me,
And poor believing I became his servant:
But most maliciously to brand my credit,
Stain my pure name.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I would not suffer it:
See him I would again, and to his teeth too:
Od's precious, I would ring him such a lesson —

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have done that already.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing:
It was too poor a purge; besides, by this time
He has found his fault, and feels the hells that follow it.
That, and your urged on anger to the highest.
Why, 'twill be such a stroke —

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Say he repent then,
And seek with tears to soften, I am a woman;
A woman that have loved him, sir, have honoured him:
I am no more.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, you may deal thereafter.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If I forgive him, I am lost.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hold there then,
The sport will be to what a poor submission —
But keep you strong.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I would not see him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes,
You shall ring his knell:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How if I kill him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Kill him: why, let him die.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know 'tis fit so.
But why should I that loved him once, destroy him?
O had he 'scaped this sin, what a brave gentleman —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I must confess, had this not fallen, a nobler,
A handsomer, the whole world had not showed ye:
And to his making such a mind.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis certain:
But all this I must now forget.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You shall not
If I have any art: go up sweet lady,
And trust my truth.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But good sir bring him not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I would not for the honour ye are born too,
But you shall see him, and neglect him too, and scorn him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You will be near me then.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will be with ye;
Yet there's some hope to stop this gap, I'll work hard. Exe.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter Antigonus, Menippus, two gent. lieutenant, and lords.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: But is it possible this fellow took it?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: It seems so by the violence it wrought with,
Yet now the fits e'en off.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I beseech your grace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, I forgive thy wife with all my heart,
And am right glad she drank it not herself,
And more glad that the virtuous maid escaped it,
I would not for the world 'thad hit: but that this soldier,
Lord how he looks, that he should take this vomit;
Can he make rhymes too?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: 'Has made a thousand sir,
And plays the burden to 'em on a jews-trump.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He looks as though he were bepissed: do you love me sir?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Yes surely even with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I thank ye;
I am glad I have so good a subject: but pray ye tell me,
How much did ye love me, before ye drank this matter?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Even as much as a sober man might; and a soldier
That your grace owes just half a year's pay to.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well remembered;
And did I seem so young and amiable to ye?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Methought you were the sweetest youth —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That's excellent.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I truly sir; and ever as I thought on ye,
I wished, and wished —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What didst thou wish I prithee?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: E'en, that I had been a wench of fifteen for ye,
A handsome wench sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why? God a mercy soldier:
I seem not so now to thee.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Not all out:
And yet I have a grudging to your grace still.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou wast never in love before?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Not with a King,
And hope I shall never be again: truly sir,
I have had such plunges, and such bickerings,
And as it were such runnings a-tilt within me,
For whatsoever it was provoked me towards ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: God-a-mercy still.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I had it with a vengeance,
It played his prize.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would not have been a wench then,
Though of this age.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: No sure, I should have spoilt ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, go thy ways, of all the lusty lovers
That ere I saw — wilt have another potion?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: If you will be another thing, have at ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha: give me thy hand, from henceforth thou art my soldier,
Do bravely, I'll love thee as much.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I thank ye;
But if you were mine enemy, I would not wish it ye:
I beseech your grace, pay me my charge.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: That's certain sir;
Has bought up all that ere he found was like ye,
Or any thing you have loved, that he could purchase;
Old horses, that your grace has ridden blind, and foundered;
Dogs, rosten hawks, and which is more than all this,
Has worn your grace's gauntlet in his bonnet.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Bring in your bills: mine own love shall be satisfied;
And sirrah, for this potion you have taken,
I'll point ye out a portion ye shall live on.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Twas the best draught that ere ye drunk.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are the princes come to'th' court?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: They are all, and lodged sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come then, make ready for their entertainment,
Which presently we'll give: wait you on me sir.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: I shall love drink the better whilst I live boys. Ex.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Let me but see her dear Leontius;
Let me but die before her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Would that would do it:
If I knew where she lay now, with what honesty,
You having flung so main a mischief on her,
And on so innocent and sweet a beauty,
Dare I present your visit?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I'll repent all:
And with the greatest sacrifice of sorrow
That ever lover made.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Twill be too late sir:
I know not what will become of you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You can help me.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: It may be to her sight: what are you nearer;
She has sworn she will not speak to ye, look upon ye,
And to love ye again, oh she cries out, and thunders,
She had rather love — there is no hope —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Yes Leontius,
There is a hope, which though it draw no love to it,
At least will draw her to lament my fortune,
And that hope shall relieve me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hark ye sir, hark ye:
Say I should bring ye —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Do not trifle with me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will not trifle; both together bring ye,
You know the wrongs ye 'Done.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I do confess 'em.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And if you should then jump into your fury,
And have another querke in your head.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I'll die first.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You must say nothing to her; for 'tis certain,
The nature of your crime will admit no excuse.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will not speak, mine eyes shall tell my penance.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You must look wondrous sad too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I need not look so,
I am truly sadness self.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That look will do it:
Stay here, I'll bring her to you instantly:
But take heed how you bear yourself: sit down there,
The more humble you are, the more she'll take compassion
Women are perilous things to deal upon. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What shall become of me? to curse my fortune,
Were but to curse my father; that's too impious;
But under whatsoever fate I suffer,
Bless I beseech thee heaven her harmless goodness.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now arm yourself.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You have not brought him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes faith,
And there he is: you see in what poor plight too,
Now you may do your will, kill him, or save him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I will go back.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will be hanged then lady,
Are ye a coward now?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I cannot speak to him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There was a sigh to blow a church down;
So, now their eyes are fixed, the small shot plays,
They will come toth' battery anon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: He weeps extremely.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Rail at him now.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nor dare believe his tears.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You may blessed beauty,
For those thick streams that troubled my repentance,
Are crept out long ago.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You see how he looks.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What have I to do how he looks? how looked he then,
When with a poisoned truth he bit mine honour,
It was your counsel too, to scorn and slight him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ay, if ye saw fit cause; and you confessed too,
Except this sin, he was the bravest gentleman,
The sweetest, noblest: I take nothing from ye,
Nor from your anger; use him as you please:
For to say truth, he had deserved your justice;
But still consider what he has been to you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pray do not blind me thus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O gentle mistress,
If there were any way to expiate
A sin so great as mine, by intercession,
By prayers, by daily tears, by dying for ye:
Oh what a joy would close these eyes that love ye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: They say women have tender hearts, I know not,
I am sure mine melts.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir, I forgive ye heartily,
And all your wrong to me I cast behind me,
And wish ye a fit beauty to your virtues:
Mine is too poor, in peace I part thus from you;
I must look back: gods keep your grace: he's here still. Ex.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: She has forgiven me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: She has directed ye:
Up, up, and follow like a man: away sir,
She looked behind her twice: her heart dwells here sir,
Ye drew tears from her too: she cannot freeze thus;
The door's set open too, are ye a man?
Are ye alive? do ye understand her meaning?
Have ye blood and spirit in ye?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I dare not trouble her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nay, and you will be nipped i'th' head with nothing,
Walk whining up and down; I dare not, I cannot:
Strike now or never: faint heart, you know what sir —
Be governed by your fear, and quench your fire out.
A devil on't stands this door open for nothing:
So get ye together, and be naught: now to secure all,
Will I go fetch out a more sovereign plaster. Ex.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter Antigonus, Seleucus, Lysimachus, Ptolomey, Lieuten. Gent. lords.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This peace is fairly made.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.l: Would your grace wish us
To put in more: take what you please, we yield it;
The honour done us by your son constrains it,
Your noble son.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is sufficient, princes;
And now we are one again, one mind, one body,
And one sword shall strike for us.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Let prince Demetrius
But lead us on: for we are his vowed servants;
Against the strength of all the world we'll buckle.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: And even from all that strength we'll catch at victory.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: O had I now recovered but the fortune
I lost in Antioch, when mine uncle perished;
But that were but to surfeit me with blessings.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: You lost a sweet child there.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Name it no more sir;
This is no time to entertain such sorrows;
Will your majesty do us the honour, we may see the prince,
And wait upon him? Enter Leon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wonder he stays from us:
How now Leontius, where's my son?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Brave captain.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Old valiant sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your graces are welcome:
Your son and't please you sir, is new cashiered yonder,
Cast from his mistress favour: and such a coil there is;
Such fending, and such proving; she stands off,
And will by no means yield to composition:
He offers any price; his body to her.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: She is a hard lady, denies that caution.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And now they whine, and now they rave: faith princes,
'Twere a good point of charity to piece 'em;
For less than such a power will do just nothing:
And if you mean to see him, there it must be,
For there will he grow, till he be transplanted.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Beseech your grace, let's wait upon you thither,
That I may see that beauty dares deny him,
That scornful beauty.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: I should think it worse now;
Ill brought up beauty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She has too much reason for't;
Which with too great a grief, I shame to think of,
But we'll go see this game.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Rather this wonder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be you our guide Leontius, here's a new peace. Ex.

div.head: Scene 5.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Thus far you shall persuade me still to honour ye,
Still to live with ye sir, or near about ye;
For not to lie, you have my first and last love,
But since you have conceived an evil against me,
An evil that so much concerns your honour,
That honour aimed by all at for a pattern:
And though there be a false thought, and confessed too,
And much repentance fallen in showers to purge it;
Yet, whilst that great respect I ever bore ye,
Dwells in my blood, and in my heart that duty;
Had it but been a dream, I must not touch ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O you will make some other happy?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Never,
Upon this hand I'll seal that faith.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: We may kiss,
Put not those out o'th' peace too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Those I'll give ye,
So there you will be pleased to pitch your ultra,
I will be merry with ye; sing, discourse with ye,
Be your poor mistress still: in truth I love ye.

div.stage: Enter Leontius, Antigonus, Seleucus, Lysimachus, Ptolemy, lieutenant, gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stay, who are these?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: A very handsome lady?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: As ere you saw.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Pity her heart's so cruel.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: How does your grace? he stands still, will not hear us.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: We come to serve ye sir, in all our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: He bows a little now; he's strangely altered.
