sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Ha? pray ye a word Leontius, pray ye a word with ye
Lysimachus? you both knew mine Enanthe,
I lost in Antioch, when the town was taken,
Mine uncle slain, Antigonus had the sack on't?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Yes, I remember well the girl.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Methinks now
That face is wondrous like her: I have her picture,
The same, but more years on her; the very same.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: A cherry to a cherry is not liker.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Look on her eyes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Most certain she is like her:
Many a time have I dandled her in these arms sir,
And I hope who will more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's that ye look at, princes?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: This picture, and that lady sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha: they are near:
They only err in time.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Did you mark that blush there?
That came the nearest.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I must speak to her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You'll quickly be resolved.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Your name sweet lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Enanthe, sir: and this to beg your blessing.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If you be the King Seleucus,
I know you are my father.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Peace a little,
Where did I lose ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: At the sack of Antioch,
Where my good uncle died, and I was taken,
By a mean soldier taken: by this prince,
This noble prince, redeemed from him again,
Wherever since I have remained his servant.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My joys are now too full: welcome Enanthe,
Mine own, my dearest, and my best Enanthe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And mine too desperate.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You shall not think so,
This is a peace indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I hope it shall be,
And ask it first.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Most royal sir, ye have it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I once more beg it thus.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You must not be denied sir.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: By me, I am sure he must not: sure he shall not;
Kneeling I give it too; kneeling I take it;
And from this hour, no envious spite ere part us.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The gods give happy joys; all comforts to ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My new Enanthe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, beat all the drums up,
And all the noble instruments of war:
Let 'em fill all the kingdom with their sounds;
And those the brazen arch of heaven break through,
While to the temple we conduct these two.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: May they be ever loving, ever young,
And ever worthy of those lines they sprung;
May their fair issues walk with time along.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: And hang a coward now; and there's my song.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: Would some man would instruct me what to say:
For this same prologue, usual to a play,
Is tied to such an old form of petition;
Men must say nothing now beyond commission:
The cloaks we wear, the legs we make, the place
We stand in, must be one; and one the face.
Nor altered, nor exceeded; if it be,
A general hiss, hangs on our levity:
We have a play, a new play to play now,
And thus low in our plays behalf we bow;
We bow to beg your suffrage, and kind ear;
If it were naught, or that it might appear
A thing buoy up by prayer, gentlemen,
Believe my faith, you should not see me then.
Let them speak then have power to stop a storm,
I never loved to feel a house so warm:
But for the play, if you dare credit me,
I think it well: all new things you shall see,
And those disposed to all the mirth that may;
And short enough we hope: and such a play
You were wont to like: sit nobly then, and see:
If it miscarry, pray look not for me.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: I am not cured yet throughly; for believe
I feel another passion that may grieve
All over me I feel it too: and now
It takes me cold, cold, cold, I know not how:
As you are good men help me, a carouse
May make me love you all, all here i'th' house,
And all that comes to see me dotingly:
Now lend your hands; and for your courtesy,
The next employment I am sent upon,
I'll swear you are physicians, the wars none.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
